comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I have a question for clarification on part b) <break/><break/>in question 2, we are told<break/><break/>"... Note that the convention we will use going forward is that vector derivatives of a scalar (with respect to a column vector) are expressed as a row vector."<break/><break/>However, in the GD update step we have</paragraph><math>P^{'}\ =\ P\ -\ \lambda\nabla_p\left(l\right)</math><paragraph>Thus, if we are taking the gradient of a scalar function (l) with respect to parameter vector P (column, by convention), the resulting gradient should be expressed as a row vector. However, this would make the subtraction incompatible. <break/><break/>Sorry if this is nit-picking, but what is the convention in this case? Is it that the gradient wrt P returns the same dimension as P, or that we take the gradient wrt P^T?</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document:
I have a question for clarification on part b) 

in question 2, we are told

"... Note that the convention we will use going forward is that vector derivatives of a scalar (with respect to a column vector) are expressed as a row vector."

However, in the GD update step we have

$$P^{'}\ =\ P\ -\ \lambda\nabla_p\left(l\right)$$

Thus, if we are taking the gradient of a scalar function (l) with respect to parameter vector P (column, by convention), the resulting gradient should be expressed as a row vector. However, this would make the subtraction incompatible. 

Sorry if this is nit-picking, but what is the convention in this case? Is it that the gradient wrt P returns the same dimension as P, or that we take the gradient wrt P^T?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi, these are two different things. What you see here is the gradient of a scalar function, which means the gradient is a column vector. From there, you can infer that $P$ is also a column vector.<break/><break/>What q2 is saying is that vector derivative a  of scalar functions is a row vector.<break/><break/>TLDR: <break/><break/>$$<break/>\frac{\partial f}{\partial \mathbf{x}} = \nabla f_{\mathbf{x}}^T<break/>$$</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Hi, these are two different things. What you see here is the gradient of a scalar function, which means the gradient is a column vector. From there, you can infer that $P$ is also a column vector.

What q2 is saying is that vector derivative a  of scalar functions is a row vector.

TLDR: 

$$
\frac{\partial f}{\partial \mathbf{x}} = \nabla f_{\mathbf{x}}^T
$$

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Okay that makes sense! Thank you</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Okay that makes sense! Thank you
